column1: Moana (also known as Vaiana or Oceania
column2: in some markets) is a 2016 American 3D computer-animated musical adventure film produced by Walt Disney Animation Studios and distributed by Walt Disney Pictures. The 56th Disney animated feature film
column3: the film is directed by Ron Clements and John Musker
column4: and co-directed by Don Hall and Chris Williams
column5: the film introduces Auliʻi Cravalho as Moana and features the voices of Dwayne Johnson
column6: Rachel House
column10: and Alan Tudyk. The film features songs written by Lin-Manuel Miranda
column12: and an orchestral score also composed by Mancina.

column1: The film tells the story of Moana
column2: the strong-willed daughter of a chief of a Polynesian village
column3: who is chosen by the ocean itself to reunite a mystical relic with the goddess Te Fiti. When a blight strikes her island
column4: Moana sets sail in search of Maui
column5: a legendary demigod
column6: in the hope of returning the relic to Te Fiti and saving her people.

column1: Moana was released theatrically in the United States on November 23
column2: 2016 to positive reviews from critics
column3: with particular praise going towards its animation
column4: music
column5: and vocal performances. The film went on to gross over $690 million worldwide. Along with Zootopia
column6: it marked the first time since 2002 that Walt Disney Animation Studios released two feature films in the same year. It received two nominations at the 89th Academy Awards: Best Animated Feature
column7: and Best Original Song ("How Far I'll Go").

column1: Puanani Cravalho (Auliʻi's mother) as Villager No. 2
After directing The Princess and the Frog (2009)
column2: Clements and Musker started working on an adaptation of Terry Pratchett's Mort
column3: but problems with acquiring the necessary film rights prevented them from continuing with that project. To avoid a recurrence of that issue
column4: they pitched three original ideas. The genesis of one of those ideas (the one that was ultimately green-lit) occurred in 2011
column5: when Musker began reading up on Polynesian mythology
column6: and learned of the heroic exploits of the demigod Māui. Intrigued with the rich culture of Polynesia
column7: he felt it would be a suitable subject for an animated film. Shortly thereafter
column8: Musker and Clements wrote a treatment and pitched it to John Lasseter
column9: who recommended that both of them should go on research trips. Accordingly
column11: Clements and Musker went on research trips to Fiji
column13: and Tahiti to meet the people of the South Pacific Ocean and learn about their culture. At first
column14: they had planned to make the film entirely about Maui
column15: but their initial research trips inspired Clements to pitch a new idea focused on the young daughter of a chief.Clements and Musker were fascinated to learn during their research that the people of Polynesia abruptly stopped making long-distance voyages about three thousand years ago. Their navigational traditions predated those of European explorers
column16: beginning around 300 CE. Native people of the Pacific possessed knowledge of the world and their place in it prior to the incursion of foreigners. For example
column17: Kānaka Maoli (Native Hawaiians) were well aware of the existence of far away islands
column19: and were interested in exploring them to benefit their societies. This voyaging heritage was made possible by a geographical knowledge system based on individual perspective rather than the European cardinal direction system. The reasons for the halt of this voyaging tradition remain unknown
column20: but scholars have offered climate change and resulting shifts in ocean currents and wind patterns as one possible explanation. Native peoples of the Pacific resumed voyaging again a thousand years later. Clements and Musker set the film at that point in time
column22: on a fictional island in the central Pacific Ocean
column23: which drew inspiration from elements of the real-life island nations of Fiji
column25: and Tonga.Over the five years it took to develop and produce the film
column26: Clements and Musker recruited experts from across the South Pacific to form an Oceanic Story Trust
column27: who consulted on the film's cultural accuracy and sensitivity as the story evolved through nine versions. The Trust responded negatively
column29: to a depiction of Maui as bald
column30: and to a proposed scene in which Moana threw a tantrum by throwing coconuts. In response
column31: Maui was reworked with long hair and the coconut scene was scrapped.During the 2015 D23 Expo's panel for Disney's slate of upcoming animated films
column32: Moana's last name was given as "Waialiki"
column33: but that name was not retained in the final film.

column1: Taika Waititi wrote the initial screenplay
column2: but went home to New Zealand in 2012 to focus on his newborn first child and What We Do in the Shadows. Years later
column3: Waititi joked that all that was left of his original draft was "EXT: OCEAN – DAY". The first draft focused on Moana as the sole daughter in a family with "five or six brothers"
column4: in which gender played into the story. However
column5: the brothers and gender-based theme were deleted from the story
column6: as the directors thought Moana's journey should be about finding herself. A subsequent draft presented Moana's father as the one who wanted to resume navigation
column7: but it was rewritten to have him oppose navigation so he would not overshadow Moana. Instead
column8: Pamela Ribon came up with the idea of a grandmother character for the film
column9: who would serve as a mentor linking Moana to ancient traditions. Another version focused on Moana rescuing her father
column10: who had been lost at sea. The film's story changed drastically during the development phase (which happens with most Disney films)
column11: and that idea ultimately survived only as a subtle element of the father's backstory.Te Kā was referred to in early drafts of the film as Te Pō
column12: a reference to the Māori goddess Hine-nui-te-pō
column13: who was originally the life-giving goddess Hine-tītama
column14: but became the goddess of death upon discovering that her husband the god Tāne was also her father. Māui set out to defeat her in order to bring immortality to humans
column15: but failed and was himself killed.Aaron and Jordan Kandell joined the project during a critical period to help deepen the emotional story architecture of the film. They are credited with developing the core relationship between Moana and Maui
column19: and the collector crab Tamatoa (played by Jemaine Clement). Jared Bush received sole credit as the writer of the final version of the screenplay.

column1: Several major story problems were identified in 2015 after the film had already transitioned from development into production
column2: but computer-generated films tend to have much shorter production schedules and much larger animation teams (in this case
column3: about 90 animators) than traditionally animated films. Since Clements and Musker were already working 12-hour days (and Saturdays) directing such a large team of animators
column4: Don Hall and Chris Williams (who had just finished directing Big Hero 6) came on board as co-directors to help fix the film's story issues. The scene in which Maui and Moana encounter the Kakamora is an intentional homage to Mad Max: Fury Road.

column1: After the filmmakers sat through auditions of hundreds of candidates from across the Pacific
column2: 14-year-old high school freshman Auliʻi Cravalho was cast as the lead character Moana. At that point in time
column3: the design of Moana's face and personality was already complete
column4: and Cravalho's obvious physical resemblance to her character was simply a coincidence. During animation production
column5: Disney animators were able to integrate some of Cravalho's mannerisms into Moana's behavior as depicted onscreen.The majority of the film's cast members are of Polynesian descent: Auliʻi Cravalho (Moana) and Nicole Scherzinger (Sina
column6: Moana's mother) were born in Hawaii and are of Native Hawaiian heritage; Dwayne Johnson (Maui)
column8: and Troy Polamalu (Villager No. 1) are of Samoan heritage; and New Zealand-born Rachel House (Tala
column12: and Jemaine Clement (Tamatoa) are of Māori heritage.

column1: Moana is Clements and Musker's first fully computer-animated film. One of the reasons for using computer animation was that the environment
column2: including the ocean
column3: benefited much more from the use of CGI as opposed to traditional animation. The filmmakers have also suggested that three-dimensional computer animation is well-suited to the "beautiful sculpturing" of the faces of the people of the South Pacific. Eric Goldberg worked on the hand-drawn animation used to depict Maui's sentient tattoos. During early development
column4: the filmmakers considered the possibility of making the film with hand-drawn traditional animation
column5: but only a few early animation tests were made in that style. In the final cut
column6: only Maui's tattoos are hand-drawn.Moana was produced in makeshift quarters in a giant warehouse in North Hollywood (together with Zootopia)
column7: while Disney Animation's headquarters building in Burbank was being renovated. Musker observed that Moana was similar in that respect to The Little Mermaid
column8: which was produced in a warehouse in Glendale. Production wrapped on October 20
